div.p: Soon, as I hope, I will see you, dearest Father Bullinger.
You will hear from the envoy of the Clavenna church what the council has responded.
The adversaries rejoice; the friends are saddened.

I give thanks to God that He finally takes me away from here, where I could no longer be of service to the church of Christ, and calls me to a place where I hope my work and ministry will not be unfruitful.
At least from there, I will be able to defend the good cause, which has been oppressed here for two and a half years, with the edification of the church.
The rest I will tell you in person.
May the Lord Jesus keep you safe with us for a long time.
Oh, miserable church of Christ, which is continually deprived of its old and best fathers and teachers, and is invaded and torn apart by new, inexperienced, and furious men.
May God have mercy on His people.

With how much sorrow I am consumed that I leave this school, indeed the entire city, in such a state, with the French church also overthrown, which has retained pure doctrine and religion here for about thirty years, you can think better than I can express in words.
Farewell then in the Lord and greet the brothers, Josias and all the others, in my name.
